articles.headline: Siemens and Alstom Form European Train Giant to Beat Chinese Competition
articles.snippet: Germany’s Siemens will combine its train unit with Alstom of France, showing how the threat from China is pushing the Continent together even as populist politics try to pull it apart.
articles.abstract: Germany’s Siemens will combine its train unit with Alstom of France, showing how the threat from China is pushing the Continent together even as populist politics try to pull it apart.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Once, the merger of two iconic European companies might well have been derailed by regional political rivalries. But in the case of a deal between Siemens and Alstom, those concerns have receded in the face of a larger threat: China.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Why Aren’t Paychecks Growing? A Burger-Joint Clause Offers a Clue
articles.snippet: Some fast-food workers are blocked from changing jobs by obscure language in franchise contracts, and economists are taking note.
articles.abstract: Some fast-food workers are blocked from changing jobs by obscure language in franchise contracts, and economists are taking note.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The American fast food industry is built on two pillars: cheap hamburgers, and cheap labor.

articles.headline: Roy Moore’s Alabama Victory Sets Off Talk of a G.O.P. Insurrection
articles.snippet: Republicans are facing rebellions from Mississippi to Arizona that could imperil their grip on Congress, as Mr. Moore’s win emboldens populist challengers.
articles.abstract: Republicans are facing rebellions from Mississippi to Arizona that could imperil their grip on Congress, as Mr. Moore’s win emboldens populist challengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Republicans are confronting an insurrection on the right that is angry enough to imperil their grip on Congress, and senior party strategists have concluded that the conservative base now loathes its leaders in Washington the same way it detested President Barack Obama.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Catalan Officials Are Squeezed as Madrid Tries to Stop Independence Vote
articles.snippet: As Sunday’s independence referendum nears, mayors risk suspension from office for violating Spain’s Constitution — or the wrath of frustrated voters.
articles.abstract: As Sunday’s independence referendum nears, mayors risk suspension from office for violating Spain’s Constitution — or the wrath of frustrated voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARENYS DE MUNT, Spain — As Spain’s government tries almost everything it can to stop an independence referendum Sunday in the restive northeastern region of Catalonia, the standoff is escalating into a constitutional crisis emblematic of the larger forces tearing at European unity.

articles.headline: Trump Tax Plan Benefits Wealthy, Including Trump
articles.snippet: The Trump administration’s tax plan provides large benefits for the wealthy, modest benefits for the middle class — and no direct benefit to the poor.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration’s tax plan provides large benefits for the wealthy, modest benefits for the middle class — and no direct benefit to the poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The tax plan that the Trump administration outlined on Wednesday is a potentially huge windfall for the wealthiest Americans. It would not directly benefit the bottom third of the population. As for the middle class, the benefits appear to be modest.

articles.headline: Twitter, With Accounts Linked to Russia, to Face Congress Over Role in Election
articles.snippet: Facebook has faced the most scrutiny over social media’s role in the 2016 election. But Twitter may have been used even more extensively by Russians.
articles.abstract: Facebook has faced the most scrutiny over social media’s role in the 2016 election. But Twitter may have been used even more extensively by Russians.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After a weekend when Americans took to social media to debate President Trump’s admonishment of N.F.L. players who do not stand for the national anthem, a network of Twitter accounts suspected of links to Russia seized on both sides of the issue with hashtags such as #boycottnfl, #standforouranthem and #takeaknee.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Scott Shane

articles.headline: IBM Now Has More Employees in India Than in the U.S.
articles.snippet: IBM has shifted its center of gravity halfway around the world to India, making it a high-tech example of the globalization trends that the Trump administration has railed against.
articles.abstract: IBM has shifted its center of gravity halfway around the world to India, making it a high-tech example of the globalization trends that the Trump administration has railed against.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — IBM dominated the early decades of computing with inventions like the mainframe and the floppy disk. Its offices and factories, stretching from upstate New York to Silicon Valley, were hubs of American innovation long before Microsoft or Google came along.

articles.headline: With Tax Cuts on the Table, Once-Mighty Deficit Hawks Hardly Chirp
articles.snippet: Senate Republicans are pressing ahead with a plan to cut taxes by up to $1.5 trillion, and those worried about the deficit have little company.
articles.abstract: Senate Republicans are pressing ahead with a plan to cut taxes by up to $1.5 trillion, and those worried about the deficit have little company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2001, when surging budget surpluses fueled hopes of extinguishing the national debt, a pitched battle broke out over President George W. Bush’s proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut. Never mind that the tax cut’s 10-year tab was supposed to leave behind more than $3 trillion in surpluses — Democrats and some Republicans said that the tax cut was just too large.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Ad-Targeting Problem, Captured in a Literal Shade of Gray
articles.snippet: Many of the social network’s ad-targeting terms are legitimate in principle but can be problematic in practice. Consider, for instance, the word “confederate.”
articles.abstract: Many of the social network’s ad-targeting terms are legitimate in principle but can be problematic in practice. Consider, for instance, the word “confederate.”
articles.lead_paragraph: For a sense of the dilemma confronting Facebook over its ad-targeting system, consider the following word: confederate.
